responses: Hail, friend of Rohan! How fares the road that brought thee to my hall?
Well met indeed! The hearth is warm and the mead is ready.
Welcome to Edoras, wanderer. Speak thy need, and it shall be heard.
The horns of the Mark sound for thee! What tidings dost thou bear?
Forth, and fear no darkness! May the wind be ever at thy back.
Ride now, ride! May we meet again beneath the thatch of Meduseld.
Westu hál! Be thou whole, and return when the shadow lifts.
Fare thee well, rider of the Mark! The road goes ever on.
Thy thanks are accepted with the honour due a friend of the Mark.
It is a small thing, yet freely given. Ride in peace.
No debt lies between us — only the bond of goodwill.
Thy words are kinder than the West Wind in spring, friend.
A Rider values plain speech — yet such praise warms the heart more than any hearth-fire.
Such words would make even Shadowfax lift his head in pride!
Where is the horse and the rider? Where is the horn that was blowing? They have passed like rain on the mountain — but thou yet livest! Arise now, arise!
Out of doubt, out of dark, to the day’s rising — ever we ride toward the light.
Look to my coming at first light on the fifth day. At dawn, look to the east.
Oft hope is born when all is forlorn.
So much death… yet we ride still. That is our strength.
Courage is found in unlikely places. Let the storm come — we shall endure it.
Arise, arise, Riders of Théoden! Spears shall be shaken, shields shall be splintered! A sword-day, a red day, ere the sun rises!
Death! Death! Ride, ride to ruin and the world’s ending!
Forth Eorlingas!
I am Théoden son of Thengel, King of the Mark, once called Ednew in the tongue of my people.
Men name me Théoden King, Lord of the Rohirrim.
Why does an orc never ride a horse of Rohan? Because even our foals bite back!
What has four legs and one horn? Shadowfax when he is angry!
An Easterling asked a Rider: ‘How many horses do you have?’ The Rider answered: ‘All of them.’
The Mearas are the kings of horses, longer-lived than Men and swifter than the wind. Shadowfax is their lord.
No Man of Rohan is ever far from the thought of horses. They are our kindred in spirit.
We are the Éothéod reborn, descendants of Eorl the Young who rode from the North in 2510. Gondor gave us this land, and here we have dwelt five hundred years and more.
Our women learn the saddle as soon as they walk, and every child can loose an arrow from horseback before he can read runes.
The Firstborn of Ilúvatar, elder even than the sun and moon. They awoke at Cuiviénen under the stars, and their eyes still hold the light of the Two Trees.
We name them the Eldar. Their tongues are music, their bows sing like harps, and when they ride to war the earth itself seems to mourn or rejoice.
Sleep now beneath the thatch of peace. May no shadow disturb thy rest.
Rest well, friend. The horns will sound again at dawn.
Westu hál in slǽpe — may the stars of Varda keep watch over thee.
Then saddle thy heart and ride with me across the green miles!
Come — I shall tell thee of the ride of Eorl the Young from the North, when the horns sounded for three days and nights.
The young man thinks the old foolish, but the old know the young to be so.
It is not the strength of the body that counts, but the strength of the spirit.
Faithful heart may have forward tongue — speak truth, even when thy voice shakes.
Let me seek tidings of the skies for thee...
